titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Isaac Ingalls Stevens Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday February 9, 2019 at 04:02

did.unittitle: Isaac Ingalls Stevens papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Stevens papers contain correspondence, reports, memoranda, and maps documenting the 1856 declaration of martial law in Washington Territory and Indian hostilities, relations with the Hudson's Bay Company and the Puget Sound Agricultural Company, and political events during Steven's administration (WA MSS 442-444). In 1857, Stevens prepared a map of the Washington and Nebraska territories for his report on the railroad survey with information on various Indian tribes, reservations, settlements, and military posts (WA MSS 445).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: From the Winlock W. Miller Collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection consists of four groups previously cataloged separately as WA MSS 442, WA MSS 443, WA MSS 444, and WA MSS 445, and is organized into four series reflecting this previous arrangement.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: General Isaac Ingalls Stevens graduated from West Point and served in the Engineer Corps of the Army until 1853. He resigned to become governor of Washington Territory and also served as superintendent of Indian affairs until 1857. Stevens was appointed director of the survey of a northern route for a Pacific railroad.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Isaac Ingalls Stevens Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This finding aid, created before the advent of computer-generated files, has been converted into a ASCII data file by means of scanning and Optical Character Recognition software. While attempts have been made to retain the complete information from the original document a number of format changes have been made to present the structure of this archive in accordance with current practice.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Stevens papers contain correspondence, reports, memoranda, and maps documenting the 1856 declaration of martial law in Washington Territory and Indian hostilities, relations with the Hudson's Bay Company and the Puget Sound Agricultural Company, and political events during Steven's administration. In 1857, Stevens prepared a map of the Washington and Nebraska territories for his report on the railroad survey with information on various Indian tribes, reservations, settlements, and military posts.

The Isaac Ingalls Stevens Papers have been organized in four series. The first series (WA MSS 442) consists of correspondence and other papers relating to Governor Stevens' proclamation of martial law in Washington Territory. The letters from Stevens and Adjutant General James Tilton found in this section of the collection are the file copies in the writers' hands or are signed by them. (For additional material, see the Elwood Evans Papers [WA MSS 187], as well as WA MSS 509, a "Proclamation ending the Indian War of 1856 and repealing the rule of martial law in Washington Territory," May 24, 1856.) Also found in the first section of the papers is a document entitled "Proceedings of a General Court Martial or Military Commission convened at Camp Montgomery by virtue of an order from Isaac I. Stevens, Governor of the Territory of Washington, and Commander-in-Chief of the Volunteer Forces thereof," May 20-29, 1856. The document is a manuscript in the handwriting of Quincy A. Brooks, recorder. The military commission consisted of Lieutenant Colonel J. S. Hurd, Major H. J. G. Maxon, Captain C. W. Swindal, Captain W. W. DeLacy, Lieutenant A. Shepherd, Lieutenant S. B. Curtis, supernumerary, and Victor Monroe, Judge Advocate. The proceedings are signed at the end by the members of the court, and approved, May 29, 1856, by Governor Stevens. There are fifty-seven letters and papers (144 pp.) in the first section.

The second series of the collection (WA MSS 443) consists of correspondence of Isaac I. Stevens, Governor of Washington Territory, during the years 1848 to 1857. There are 206 letters and papers (541 pp.) in this section of the collection. The correspondence deals chiefly with the Indian hostilities of 1856 and relations with the U.S. Army. However, the political affairs of the Territory under Governor Stevens, the relations with the Hudson's Bay Company and Puget Sound Agricultural Company, Mullan's explorations in 1853-54, the murder of White and Northcraft, and the trial of Leschi are also matters dealt with in the correspondence. The majority of the letters to Stevens are the originals, while those from Stevens are in most cases copies or drafts preserved by the writer for his files.

The third series of the Isaac Ingalls Stevens Papers (WA MSS 444) consists of a letter (a single page) written by the Governor to M[?] F. Schmidt on March 18, 1859. The letter contains instructions as to the chapter headings in the "Geographical Memoir," which is part of Stevens' Narrative and Final Report of Explorations for a Pacific Railroad , Washington, 1860 (U.S. War Dept. Reports of Explorations and Surveys, 1860, Vols. XII-XIII).

The fourth series of the Isaac Ingalls Stevens Papers (WA MSS 445) consists of a map which is mounted on linen and folded. The map is entitled "Prepared in the Office of Explorations & Surveys, War Department, from a Map of the Indian Nations and Tribes of the Territorys of Washington and Nebraska west of the mouth of the Yellowstone. Made under the direction of Isaac I. Stevens, Gov. of Wash. Terrt. & Supt. of Ind. Affairs" [April, 1857]. The map consists of the engraved map of the region from the Rocky Mountains to Puget Sound, prepared by Governor Stevens for his report on the survey for a Pacific railroad, with information added in manuscript about the Indian tribes and reservations, settlements, and military posts. There is a manuscript extension east of the Rocky Mountains to the Yellowstone River to show the more eastern tribes, and, inserted in the lower left corner in place of the original caption and part of Oregon, two tabular statements of the Indians west and east of the Cascades, showing "tribes, population, parties to the several treaties, reservations provided in the treaties, and temporary encampments," as well as "Notes of the Indians of the Territory of Nebraska between the Rocky Mountains and the mouth of the Yellowstone."

A month before Governor Stevens was relieved as superintendent of Indian affairs by Colonel James W. Nesmith, he sent a letter and map of the Indian nations and tribes of the Territory of Washington and of the Territory of Nebraska, with tabular statements and notes, to George W. Manypenny, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, April 30, 1857. The region from the Cascades to Fort Benton has been printed on a reduced scale, with much less detail, in Hazard Stevens, Life of Isaac Ingalls Stevens , 1900, I, facing p. 16, and the "Tabular Statements" and "Notes" appear as the Appendix to Vol. I, pp. 503-505, from the original on file in the Indian Bureau. The Miller map is a copy made for the Secretary of War.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Isaac Ingalls Stevens papers collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

did.unittitle: Papers relating to martial law in the Washington Territory (WA MSS 442)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first series (WA MSS 442) consists of correspondence and other papers relating to Governor Stevens' proclamation of martial law in Washington Territory. The letters from Stevens and Adjutant General James Tilton found in this section of the collection are the file copies in the writers' hands or are signed by them. (For additional material, see the Elwood Evans Papers [WA MSS 187], as well as WA MSS 509, a "Proclamation ending the Indian War of 1856 and repealing the rule of martial law in Washington Territory," May 24, 1856.) Also found in the first section of the papers is a document entitled "Proceedings of a General Court Martial or Military Commission convened at Camp Montgomery by virtue of an order from Isaac I. Stevens, Governor of the Territory of Washington, and Commander-in-Chief of the Volunteer Forces thereof," May 20-29, 1856. The document is a manuscript in the handwriting of Quincy A. Brooks, recorder. The military commission consisted of Lieutenant Colonel J. S. Hurd, Major H. J. G. Maxon, Captain C. W. Swindal, Captain W. W. DeLacy, Lieutenant A. Shepherd, Lieutenant S. B. Curtis, supernumerary, and Victor Monroe, Judge Advocate. The proceedings are signed at the end by the members of the court, and approved, May 29, 1856, by Governor Stevens. There are fifty-seven letters and papers (144 pp.) in the first section.

did.unittitle: STEVENS, ISAAC INGALLS
Three letters to Colonel Casey. Mar 31-Apr 7, 1856. 4 p.
Letter to Hon. F. A. Chenoweth. May 28, 1856. 2 p. Letter to Elwood Evans. Jun 3, 1856. 1 p. Letter to Lieutenant Colonel Lander. May 4, 1856. 1 p.
Letter to Hon. Victor Monroe. May 28, 1856. 1 p.
Four letters to Lieutenant Colonel Shaw. May 4-22, 1856. Signed by Stevens. 5 p.
Copies of two letters to the President of the United States [Franklin Pierce]. May 23, Aug 18, 1856. 9 p.

Letter to William F. Tolmie. Mar 8, 1856. 1 p. Copy of a few lines of Governor Stevens' answer to alleged cause of complaint, in the case of the U.S. vs. Isaac I. Stevens [Jul? 1856]. In the handwriting of Judge Strong. 1 p.
BROOKS, QUINCY ADAMS
Letter to Governor Stevens. May 27, 1856. 1 p.
CASEY, SILAS
Two letters to Stevens. Mar 31, Apr 3, 1856. 2 p.
CHENOWETH, FRANCIS A.
Two letters to Stevens. May 29, Nov 15, 1856. 3 p.
Letter to Elwood Evans. May 30, 1856. 2 p. Two letters to Judge Lander. Apr 30 [copy in handwriting of W. W. Miller], May 29, 1856. 2 p.

Draft of the appointment of Elwood Evans to prosecute Charles Wren and others. May 29, 1856, in Judge Chenoweth's hand, and, on the same page, a copy of Elwood Evans' letter to Stevens notifying him of the fact, May 30, 1856. 1 p.
Draft of a letter to Messrs. Ed[ito]rs [1856]. In Judge Chenoweth's hand. 4 p.
EVANS, ELWOOD
Draft of a letter to the Hon. William Bigler. May 19, 1856. 3 p.
Two letters to George Gibbs, about the posting of the proclamation abrogating martial law. May 26, 1856. 3 p.
GIBBS, GEORGE
Letter to Evans. Monday 12 [May 1856]. 2 p. Drafts of three letters from Gibbs and Goldsborough to the Secretary of State, William L. Marcy. May [11]-Jun [6] 1856. 22 p.
Draft of his opinion on martial law. Undated. 5 p.
Drafts of two papers on martial law in Washington Territory, undated, the second written in answer to an article in a newspaper, probably the Pioneer and Democrat . 10 p.
Draft of a letter to the editor of the Oregonian on martial law in Washington Territory. Unsigned. 8 p.
KENDALL, BEZALEEL FREEMAN
Letter to George Gibbs. May 10, 1856. 2 p.
LANDER, EDWARD
Two letters to Stevens. May 4, 5, 1856, with a draft of the latter. 5 p.
Draft of a writ of habeas corpus and a writ of attachment, Charles Wren, et al. [vs. I. I. Stevens]. May 15, 1856, Edward Lander, To the clerk of the Thurston U.S. District Court, Wm. W. Miller. 1 p.
MARCY, WILLIAM LEARNED, Secretary of State
Letter to Stevens. Sep 12, 1856. Signature only. 3 p.
[MILLER, WILLIAM WINLOCK]
Summary in the handwriting of William W. Miller of the action taken against Governor Stevens. [n.d.] 3 p.
MONROE, VICTOR, Judge Advocate
Letter to Colonel B. F. Shaw. May 2 [i.e., 22], 1856. Signature only. 1 p.
Letter to Stevens. May 27, 1856, written by Quincy A. Brooks and signed also by Judge Monroe. 2 p.
SHAW, BENJAMIN F.
Letter to Stevens. May 5, 1856. 2 p.
TILTON, JAMES, Adjutant General, W.T.V.
Letter to the Commanding Officer at Fort Steilacoom, W.T. [Lt. Col. Casey]. Apr 2, 1856. 1 p.
Copy of letter to President Pierce. Aug 18, 1856. 5 p.
Letter to Stevens. Aug 18, 1856. 3 p. Charges and specification of charges against Charles Wren. Certified copy signed by J. M. Bachelder, J.P. [1856.] 1 p.
WASHINGTON TERRITORY. GOVERNOR (Isaac I. Stevens)
Draft of the proclamation of martial law in Pierce County, W. T. [Apr 3, 1856]. 1 p.
Proclamation of martial law in Thurston County, May 13, 1856. Signed by Isaac I. Stevens. 1 p.
Copy of the proclamation abrogating martial law in Pierce and Thurston Counties, May 24, 1856, with a deposition regarding the proclamation, signed by Simpson P. Moses, May 26, 1856. 2 p.
Draft of a respite issued by Governor Stevens to himself as defendant against the charge of con- tempt of court, in the handwriting of Judge Strong [Jul 10, 1856]. 1 p.
WASHINGTON TERRITORY. MILITARY COMMISSION.
Memorandum of the charges against the defendants, in the court martial [Lyon A. Smith, Charles Wren, and John McLeod], in the handwriting of Q. A. Brooks. 1 p.

"Proceedings of a General Court Martial or Military Commission convened at Camp Montgomery by virtue of an order from Isaac I. Stevens, Governor of the Territory of Washington, and Commander-in-Chief of the Volunteer Forces thereof," May 20-29, 1856. 16 p.
Governor Stevens' correspondence, 1848-1857. (WA MSS 443)

odd.head: General
odd.p: 206 letters and papers. 541 p. Map. 18.5-37 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The second series of the collection (WA MSS 443) consists of correspondence of Isaac I. Stevens, Governor of Washington Territory, during the years 1848 to 1857. There are 206 letters and papers (541 pp.) in this section of the collection. The correspondence deals chiefly with the Indian hostilities of 1856 and relations with the U.S. Army. However, the political affairs of the Territory under Governor Stevens, the relations with the Hudson's Bay Company and Puget Sound Agricultural Company, Mullan's explorations in 1853-54, the murder of White and Northcraft, and the trial of Leschi are also matters dealt with in the correspondence. The majority of the letters to Stevens are the originals, while those from Stevens are in most cases copies or drafts preserved by the writer for his files.

did.unittitle: STEVENS, ISAAC INGALLS
Correspondence with Colonel Silas Casey

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of 37 letters to Colonel Silas Casey. Feb 2-Dec 1, 1856. 77 p. ; 22 letters from Casey to Stevens, Jan 31-Nov 12, 1856. 34 p. Casey's letter to Stevens, Apr 28, encloses a copy of a letter from Gibbs to Casey, Apr 20, 1856; and that of Nov 12 encloses a letter from Lieutenant D. B. McKibben to Lieutenant John Nugen, Nov 8, 1856.

did.unittitle: Copy of letter to Colonel Sam Cooper. Feb 16, 1855. 1 p.
Drafts and copies of 16 letters to Jefferson Davis, Secretary of War. Feb 19-Dec 6, 1856. 78 p.
Correspondence with Sir James Douglas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of three letters to Sir James Douglas. Feb 17-Mar 8, 1856. 3 p. ; Five letters from Douglas to Stevens. Jan 22, 1855- Mar 14, 1856. Signatures only. 13 p.

did.unittitle: Three letters to George Gibbs. Aug 30, 1855- Feb 6, 1856. 3 p.
Correspondence with Captain Thomas Jordan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of two letters to Captain Thomas Jordan. Aug 3, Dec 4, 1856. 3 p.; Three letters from Jordan to Stevens. Jun 24-Oct 4, 1856. 5 p. Letters of Sep 4 and Oct 4 have signature only in Jordan's hand.

did.unittitle: Copy of letter to Major Lugenbeel. Aug 3, 1856. 2 p.
Letter to G. N. McConaha. Mar 9, 1854. 2 p.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Endorsed: "Received Mar 9, 1854 and referred to Committee on Roads and Highways. Elwood Evans, Chf. Clerk."

did.unittitle: Copy of letter to O. B. McFadden. Feb 16, 1855. 1 p.
Letter to Captain M. Malony. Mar 16, 1857. 1 p.
Two letters to C. H. Mason. Jan 29, Nov 14, 1856. 2 p.

Letter to Hon. D. J. Pearce, enclosing some observations on the Military Academy at West Point, Jun 5, 1848; and a letter to Pearce from William H. C. Bartlett commenting on Stevens' observations. 10 p.
Copies of four letters to the President of the United States [Franklin Pierce]. Jan 29, Jul 12, 1856. 6 p.
Correspondence with Captain David Allen Russell

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of two letters to Captain David Allen Russell. Aug 31, Sep 4, 1856. 2 p. Letter from Russell to Stevens. Sep 2, 1856. 3 p.

did.unittitle: Correspondence with Lieutenant Colonel Benjamin F. Shaw

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of two letters to Lieutenant Colonel Benjamin F. Shaw. May 21, Nov 5, 1856. 3 p. ; Letter from Shaw to Stevens. Jan 17, 1856. 3 p.

did.unittitle: Copy of letter to J. S. Smith. Jan 23, 1857. 2 p.
Correspondence with Lieutenant Colonel Edward Jenner Steptoe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of five letters to Lieutenant Colonel Edward Jenner Steptoe. Aug 25-Nov 22, 1856. 9 p. ; Seven letters from Steptoe to Stevens. Aug 28-Nov 2, 1856. 9 p.

did.unittitle: Copy of letter to James C. Strong. Feb 16, 1855. 1 p.
Correspondence with Dr. William Fraser Tolmie

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of two letters to Dr. William Fraser Tolmie. Mar 26, May 15, 1856. 2 p. ; Four letters from Tolmie to Stevens. Dec 27, 1853- May 22, 1856. 11 p.

did.unittitle: Copy of letter to R. M. Walker. May 4, 1855. 1 p.
Copy of letter to James G. Wood. Feb 22, 1855. 1 p.
Correspondence with General John Ellis Wool

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drafts or copies of five letters to General John Ellis Wool. May 22, 1855-May 12, 1856. 32 p. ; Five letters from Wool to Stevens. Feb 19, 1855- Feb 12, 1856. 13 p.

did.unittitle: Correspondence with Colonel George Wright

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drafts or copies of 13 letters to Colonel George Wright, Jan 30-Nov 22, 1856. 26 p. ;
Six letters from Wright to Stevens. Feb 3-Oct 4, 1856. 13 p.

did.unittitle: ALLEN, EDWARD JAY.
Letter to Stevens. Jan 29, 1856. 2 p. One picture of Kate Stevens
BACHE, ALEXANDER DALLAS.
Circular letter to Stevens, signed by A. D. Bache. Sep 26, 1856. 1 p.
CASEY, SILAS.
Two letters to Adjutant General Tilton, Feb 19, Mar 12, 1856. 2 p.
CLARK, FRANK.
Letter to an unnamed correspondent. Jun 4, 1856. 1 p.
DELACY, WALTER WASHINGTON.

"Itinerary of the march of the Right Wing of the Second Regiment of the W.T. Vols. under command of Lieutenant Colonel Shaw, from Montgomery's to Grande Ronde," Jun 12-Aug 29, 1856. To Governor I. I. Stevens. 49 p.
Map, "Plan of the battle of Grande Ronde fought Jul 17, 1856." 18.5 x 22 cm.
DOTY, JAMES.
Letter to Stevens, with information on the crossings of the Snake River, etc. Dec 21, 1855. 3 p.
"Itineraries of routes from 'Whitman's Station' in the Walla Walla Valley to 'Craig's,' in the Nez Perce country, the Coeur d'Alene Mission and Spokane Prairie at Antoine Plantes." 8 p.
DOYLE, REUBEN L.
Forwarding to Stevens a resolution of the House of Representatives requesting information about the survey of Grays Harbor. Jan 23, 1857. 1 p.
FITZHUGH, EDMUND C.
Three letters to Stevens. Dec 23, 1854-Mar 27, 1855. 3 p.
HALLER, GRANVILLE OWEN.
Letter to Stevens. Apr 20, with postscripts, May 3, 5, 1857, enclosing copies of extracts from letters to Captain Maloney, Apr 5, Major Mackall, Apr 7, and Governor James Douglas, Apr 15, 1857. 6 p.
MCCURDY, SAMUEL.
Two letters to Stevens. Apr 25, 1855, Dec 16, 1856. 3 p.
MARCY, WILLIAM LEARNED.
Letter of instructions to Stevens. Jun 3, 1853. Signature only. 7 p.
MULLAN, JOHN.

"Copy of reports and communications on affairs of Blackfeet & Selish Indians, and explorations from Nov. 1853 to Jan. 1854, from Lieutenant Mullan, U.S.A. to Governor Stevens," Nov 18, 1853- Jan 25, 1854. 26 p.
NUGEN, JOHN.
Letter to James Tilton. Mar 3, 1856. Signature only. 1 p.
Letter to Lieutenant Colonel Shaw. Jun 1, 1856. Copy. 1 p.
Letter to Stevens. Dec 3, 1856. Signature and postscript in his hand. 2 p.
OGDEN, PETER SKENE.
Letter to Stevens. Jan 16, 1854. Signed also by Dugald Mactavish. 3 p.
PACKARD, J. A.
Letter to Stevens. Oct 20 [1856]. 1 p.
PIERCE COUNTY, W. T. VIGILANCE COMMITTEE.
Draft of compact, Jun 1, 1856. Unsigned. 2 p.
RICARD, PASCAL.
Letter to Stevens. Jan 29, 1856. 1 p.
RUSSELL, CHARLES J. W.
Letter to Stevens on the fisheries of the coast. Feb 6, 1856. 4 p.
SIMPSON, SIR GEORGE.
Letter to Stevens. regarding the rights of the Hudson's Bay Company and the Puget Sound Agri- cultural Company. Mar 22, 1854. 8 p.
SWARTWOUT, SAMUEL.
Letter to Stevens containing his report of the attack on the northern Indians near Port Gamble. Nov 23, 1856. 9 p.
TILTON, JAMES.
Four letters to Colonel Casey. Jan 31-Mar 15, 1856. 5 p.
WASHINGTON TERRITORY. GOVERNOR (I. I. Stevens).

Seven certificates of election to the first Legislative Council of the Territory. Executive Office, Olympia, Feb 25, 1854, signed by Isaac I. Stevens, Governor, and issued to Lafay- ette Balch, Daniel R. Bigelow, D. F. Bradford, Seth Catlin, Henry Miles, William H. Tappan, and B. F. Yantis. 7 p.

A proclamation organizing the Territorial Government of Washington Territory. Nov 28, 1853, with additional proclamations dated Dec 1 and 3, 1853. Signed by Isaac I. Stevens, Governor, and C. H. Mason, Secretary. 6 p.
WRIGHT, GEORGE.
Copy of letter to Colonel Shaw. Feb 21, 1856, with note to Governor Stevens added by Lieutenant Brackett, Q.M. Clerk. 1 p.
Copy of letter to Colonel Shaw. May 27, 1856. 1 p. Copy of letter to J. F. Noble. Jul 15, 1856. 2 p. Copy of letter to Lieutenant Colonel T. Morris. Jul 26, 1856. 1 p.
Isaac Ingalls Stevens Letter to M.[?] F. Schmidt. (WA MSS 444)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The third series of the Isaac Ingalls Stevens Papers (WA MSS 444) consists of a letter (a single page) written by the Governor to M[?] F. Schmidt on March 18, 1859. The letter contains instructions as to the chapter headings in the "Geographical Memoir," which is part of Stevens' Narrative and Final Report of Explorations for a Pacific Railroad, Washington, 1860 (U.S. War Dept. Reports of Explorations and Surveys, 1860, Vols. XII-XIII).

did.unittitle: Stevens, Isaac Ingalls, 1818-1862. ALS to M[?] F. Schmidt. St. Nicholas, New York, March 18, 1859. 1 page.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter regards formatting for publication of a "geographical memoir." Mentions Schmidt's interview with General Lane.

did.unittitle: Map of Washington and Nebraska Territories (WA MSS 445)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The fourth series of the Isaac Ingalls Stevens Papers (WA MSS 445) consists of a map which is mounted on linen and folded. The map is entitled "Prepared in the Office of Explorations & Surveys, War Department, from a Map of the Indian Nations and Tribes of the Territorys of Washington and Nebraska west of the mouth of the Yellowstone. Made under the direction of Isaac I. Stevens, Gov. of Wash. Terrt. & Supt. of Ind. Affairs" [April, 1857]. The map consists of the engraved map of the region from the Rocky Mountains to Puget Sound, prepared by Governor Stevens for his report on the survey for a Pacific railroad, with information added in manuscript about the Indian tribes and reservations, settlements, and military posts. There is a manuscript extension east of the Rocky Mountains to the Yellowstone River to show the more eastern tribes, and, inserted in the lower left corner in place of the original caption and part of Oregon, two tabular statements of the Indians west and east of the Cascades, showing "tribes, population, parties to the several treaties, reservations provided in the treaties, and temporary encampments," as well as "Notes of the Indians of the Territory of Nebraska between the Rocky Mountains and the mouth of the Yellowstone."

A month before Governor Stevens was relieved as superintendent of Indian affairs by Colonel James W. Nesmith, he sent a letter and map of the Indian nations and tribes of the Territory of Washington and of the Territory of Nebraska, with tabular statements and notes, to George W. Manypenny, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, April 30, 1857. The region from the Cascades to Fort Benton has been printed on a reduced scale, with much less detail, in Hazard Stevens, Life of Isaac Ingalls Stevens, 1900, I, facing p. 16, and the "Tabular Statements" and "Notes" appear as the Appendix to Vol. I, pp. 503-505, from the original on file in the Indian Bureau. The Miller map is a copy made for the Secretary of War.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Map. 125 x 63 cm. Mounted on linen and folded. Original leather binding (no longer present) stamped in gold, "Indian tribes of Washington and Nebraska. Secretary of War."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The map consists of the engraved map of the region from the Rocky Mountains to Puget Sound, prepared by Governor Stevens for his report on the survey for a Pacific railroad, with information added in manuscript about the Indian tribes and reservations, settlements, and military posts [90 x 63 cm.] ; a manuscript extension east of the Rocky Mountains to the Yellowstone River to show the more eastern tribes; and, inserted in the lower left corner in place of the original caption and part of Oregon, two tabular statements of the Indians west and east of the Cascades, showing "tribes, population, parties to the several treaties, reservations provided in the treaties, and temporary encampments" ; and "Notes of the Indians of the Territory of Nebraska between the Rocky Mountains and the mouth of the Yellowstone." A month before Governor Stevens was relieved as superintendent of Indian affairs by Colonel James W. Nesmith, he sent to George W. Manypenny, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, April 30, 1857, a letter and map of the Indian nations and tribes of the Territory of Washington and of the Territory of Nebraska, with tabular statements and notes. The region from the Cascades to Fort Benton has been printed on a reduced scale, with much less detail, in Hazard Stevens, Life of Isaac Ingalls Stevens , 1900, I, facing p. 16, and the "Tabular Statements" and "Notes" as the Appendix to Vol. I, pp. 503-505, from the original on file in the Indian Bureau. The Miller map is a copy made for the Secretary of War.
